Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Designing Reflective Opportunities in Human-Computer Interaction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many people presently interact more with and through computers than they do with other people directly but such interaction may have negative effects that go unobserved. These balance of positive and negative effects could be considered more thoughtfully if the design of the technology created opportunities for reflection, e.g., by creating "seams" in interaction that make the balance between the machine's influence and the human push-back more obvious, or by allowing people to nudge one another and themselves in particular directions. The goal of this project is to create at least one proof-of-concept implementation and demonstration of such a reflective design that will provide a paradigm or model for similar development and serve as a basis for future research. The pilot project has four parts: development of a task and example reflective opportunity, technology and experimental development, conduct of an experiment and analysis.

The project is important because of the enormous role that computer systems play in the interstices of everyday existence, because the influences that computer systems have are not necessarily well-understood by users, creators or analysts and because of the potential for novel and more beneficial approaches to design that bring these influences to greater awareness. If the project succeeds in demonstrating the value of a reflective design approach, it may influence the ways people in society conceptualize computation, increasing their awareness of the need to cultivate a pro-active stance as users and designers and so provide a new paradigm for human-computer interaction research and development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we looked in more detail at a puzzling social phenomenon uncovered by our prior work, and designed a user interface to influence the phenomenon. Previously, we had three people play a shared version of Sudoku on their computers. Each had their own laptop, as they sat in the same room across a table from one another. In this version of the game, all players could enter numbers at any time. Most people talked with one another during the game to help them decide whether a particular move was correct or not. In about ¼ of the games, we were surprised that no one said anything to anyone else! Could it have been that using a computer was so involving that they did not feel able to talk about the game?

We investigated this by creating what we called a “nudger” – an element of the user interface to the game that would expressly call attention to the possibility of interacting with other players about what is going on. The “nudger” we was a simple button labeled “HOLD ON” which prevents any new entries in the game until the person who hit the button cleared it. Our theory was that the presence of the button – even if it was never used – would make players more aware of the possibility of talking with other players.

This kind of question arises from our observations of situations where people are working with computers while in the same place as other people. We call this situation “Triple Space” as shown in the attached diagram. When playing Sudoku in "triple space," people must manage (1) complex problem-solving tasks, (2) social interaction, and (3) the meaning making process of the changing representation created by others on shared mediums. (We realized that what we saw in the Sudoku game was not so different from couples who text each other in bed – YES that is actually something that modern couples seem to do!) The triple space interaction model shows how technology opens up multiple ways to coordinate joint activities for co-located people, but it also hints at how the changes can estrange us from the everyday activities we used to take for granted.

We conducted many study sessions which were video recorded and are still being minutely analyzed to see, if and how, the nudger worked. It takes two or three hours to transcribe and code one hour of video; we have used this as an opportunity to engage 16 undergraduates in the research process. It is our hope that this opportunity will encourage these students – many from under-represented groups – to continue on in the study of human-computer interaction. The work was coordinated by a post-doctoral researcher and a dedicated and talented recent graduate who is on her way to graduate school.

This work is both high reward and high risk:

-       Computer systems play an enormous role in everyday life but their influences are not necessarily well-understood by user, creators or analysts. Understanding leads to novel and more beneficial approaches to design. In a short period of time, computerization has moved from providing a counterpoint to life, with the potential to highlight and shade experience, to constituting a constant force, almost defining our experience of life. This makes computerization like government: we mostly all agree that government is a good thing, but we may not agree about exactly how, when, where and why it should operate.

- It is high risk because both expert and popular imagination are so oriented towards the creation of smooth, unnoticeable user experiences, that it is difficult to imagine a process that creates alternatives.
